data.title: repositoryForDirectory promise matching versus setPaths disposing
data.body:
It is possible for `atom.project.repositoryForDirectory` to return a disposed `GitRepository`, that is one with `@emitter === null`, because `atom.project.setPaths` calls `.destroy()` on all loaded repositories, but  references to the (now destroyed) repositories are kept in `@repositoryPromisesByPath`.  I see this with `project-ring` which calls `setPaths` on startup, leading to a number of errors of startup (with `project-ring`) of the form:

```
Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read property 'on' of null
   module.exports.GitRepository.onDidChangeStatus @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/git-repository.js:127
   module.exports.TabView.subscribeToRepo @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/tabs/lib/tab-view.js:343
   (anonymous function) @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/tabs/lib/tab-view.js:328
   _tickCallback @ node.js:368
```

Let me know if more detailed reproduction steps are needed.

data.title: Package menus access key issue on Darwin
data.body:
The [Tool Bar](https://github.com/suda/tool-bar/) package [provides a menu item](https://github.com/suda/tool-bar/blob/master/menus/tool-bar.cson) for the packages menu. The label contains an ampersand to define access keys on the supported platforms (Windows & Linux). But because the label begins with an ampersand, on Darwin the Tool Bar menu item is sorted as first item. Aldo this is great advertisement, some people have [reported it](https://github.com/suda/tool-bar/issues/97) (and I agree).

After some digging I found the following: the package menu is sorted [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/7d743827820969871e8724e6f353887a3ddfc105/src/menu-manager.coffee#L67) by [function here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/7d743827820969871e8724e6f353887a3ddfc105/src/menu-manager.coffee#L203) which [normalizes every menuitem](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/8427196d87e06c5cda2ba9568f518539b27bb1e1/src/menu-helpers.coffee#L40), except for [Darwin](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/8427196d87e06c5cda2ba9568f518539b27bb1e1/src/menu-helpers.coffee#L43).

Apparently the ampersand is still stripped out when visible on screen, but not for sorting. This looks like a (minor) bug to me.

I haven't found a way to define separate menu configs per platform (like Atom does with it's [own menu's](https://github.com/atom/atom/tree/master/menus)), but please correct me if I've missed something.

---

_Atom 1.4.0 & 1.5.0-beta0_

data.title: Require package's main module in legacy activateConfig method
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10426

I haven't added tests for this because I want to remove this method somewhat soon (once https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9974 is finished and we deprecate specifying config schemas in package's main modules).

data.title: Atom Linux deletes data on remote filesystems
data.body:
Atom on Linux deletes data on remote filesystems like sshfs in a somewhat contrived but real worlds scenario (this has happened to me twice now):
1. Remote FS is mounted, open file in Atom.
2. Close Atom. Filename is saved so it is automatically opened next time Atom is started.
3. Unmount FS.
4. Open Atom. File is automatically opened, but because it is not mounted, the buffer is empty.
5. Mount remote FS.
6. Switch to the empty buffer file.
7. Contents of file are now deleted, i.e. Atom saved its empty buffer to the disk, overwriting the existing data with nothing. No prompt or warning is given to the user.

This is happening on Atom 1.4.0.

data.title: Atom is lossing contributions and users due to third-party Electron-based IDEs
data.body:
I think that the existence of third-party IDEs based on Electron is killing Atom, because they are improving many things that later don't get implemented into Atom. Wouldn't be great to have a only IDE with all the improvements?

I think that doing rebrandings of Atom to add some functionality is not as great as some development teams (_cough_ MS) can think. Maybe would be better to join all the efforts here?

The only doubt I have is: Is my issue on-topic? I post here because there isn't Gitter account on the Atom repository.

data.title: Edition unresponsive/slow with a 300k json file
data.body:
Hi,

overall, Atom is the best editor out there. None Obstante, I got an issue when editing a 300k json file.

Especially, when using "search/replace" dialog (bottom bar visible + search result highlight)
(if you just open it, and do no search nor edition : no problem)

The editor get slow or freez ("not responsive" system dialog). The key press stop being process until atom "wake up" and process them all at once.

my json:
- file extension : ".jsonExtra"
- 330k (please, don't call that "big")
- max line length : 400char
- num of line: 7300
- a valid json with some unicode char
- no syntaxe higlight / nor folding activated

The json is generated using python code:

```
          jsonFile = codecs.open(jsonFileName, 'w', encoding='utf-8')
          out = json.dumps(self.jsondata, sort_keys=True, indent=4, ensure_ascii=False)
          jsonFile.write(out)
```

my system:
- Ubunutu 14.04 LTS / 64 bit / locale:EN
- Atom version 1.3.0 (from help menu) / locale: EN
- clean install : No special extension / plugin. I did disable the "whitespace" extension.
- dual monitor (atom on secondary monitor)
- proc : Intel® Core™ i5-4590 CPU @ 3.30GHz × 4
- with "atom --safe" the problem does not reproduce
- with "atom" and some extension disable(find-and-replace, language-json, spell-check, whitespace, Autocomplete Atom Api), the system dialog does not pop up, but atom is slower that you could expect for a 300k file. (on my system, gedit can edit this file without problem. very fluid)

I did report the issue in atom's project (and not to the extensions' project) because it seem to be a "cumulative" issue. Like if the extension were using all the CPU time of the process.

related ?
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6607
- https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2902

regards,

data.title: Switch Atom To Use electron-compile Instead Of Built-In compile-cache
data.body:
Babel 6.x has a new plugin architecture which breaks assumptions used to transpile + cache Babel in 3rd party packages. babel-core looks for the plugins and presets (specified below) in directories relative to the .js file being transpiled. Thus, because the plugins and presets are included in `${PATH_TO_ATOM}/node_modules` (and not `~/.atom/packages/some-random-package/node_modules`), they are not found. There is no way to give babel-core a root directory from which to search.

This leaves us with two paths forward:
1. Submit a PR to `babel-core` to add an [option](http://babeljs.io/docs/usage/options/) for specifying a `presetRoot` and a `pluginRoot`
2. Require 3rd party packages wishing to use `babel` to add the required packages to their package.json
## Migration Notes:
- [ ] Update `static/babelrc.json`:
  - [ ] Clear file
  - [ ] Add `"presets": ["es2015", "stage-0", "react"]`
  - [ ] Add `"plugins" : ["syntax-async-functions"]`
  - [ ] Add `"sourceMaps": "inline"`
- [ ] Add in babel-polyfill at needed locations:
  - [ ] `static/index.html`?
  - [ ] `src/browser/main.coffee`?
- [ ] Update `package.json` and `build/package.json`
- [ ] Update `build/Gruntfile.coffee`
### `package.json`

``` json
"babel-core": "^6.4.5",
"babel-plugin-syntax-async-functions": "^6.3.13",
"babel-polyfill": "^6.3.14",
"babel-preset-es2015": "^6.3.13",
"babel-preset-stage-0": "^6.3.13",
"babel-preset-react": "^6.3.13",
```
### `Gruntfile.coffee`

```
  babelConfig =
    options:
      extends: '../static/babelrc'
    dist:
      files: [
        expand: true
        src: [
          'src/**/*.js'
        ]
        dest: appDir
      ]
```

This is related to #10509.

data.title: Modify mouse behaviour
data.body:
I think it would be nice if users could modify mouse behaviour similar to how we can modify key bindings. My main reasoning for this is that I have recently switched from Windows to Linux and have learned that middle mouse pasting is not only a thing, but deeply ingrained into X itself. This is frustrating for me because an Atom add-on I can't live without, **Sublime-Style-Column-Selection** simply does not work on Linux. If I set it to use the left mouse button, that disables my ability to click and drag to select text. If I set it to middle mouse, I end up pasting junk everywhere, and if I set it to right mouse, well, it just pops up menus instead.

I use this feature about 9000 times a day, and not being able to use it is killing me. I know that Atom was recently "fixed" to comply with X's nonsense, but there seems to be no simple way to revert to using sane controls.

data.title: Folds and selections seem to interact
data.body:
Adding selections seems to invalidate folds in the latest version of atom and in safe mode.
Is this expected or am I missing something?
I thought they were independent layers.

If it's unexpected, I would be willing to take a look too. :)

Steps to reproduce:
- Open e.g. spec/fixtures/sample.js
- Open the developer console.
- Run:

```
editor = atom.workspace.getTextEditors()[0]
editor.foldBufferRow(4)
editor.setSelectedBufferRange([[3, 0], [4, 0]])
```
- The fold disappears.

data.title: Improve working with folds
data.body:
Hi,

I've been looking into making working with folds a bit smoother to fix #8023.

The functionality in this PR:
- Allows the end of the fold line on the screen to represent the end of the fold in the buffer. This makes us able to delete up until the boundaries of folds.
- More conservative fold expansion: only expand a fold when necessary.
- More conservative deletion: removed some cases where the entire fold would be deleted.

Let me know what you think!
I'm pretty new to CoffeeScript so any comments are welcome!

A demo:
![demo](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2732330/12545551/30d26450-c2f8-11e5-802c-ae81477985bd.gif)

data.title: Atom is not signed using SHA256 hashes
data.body:
http://textslashplain.com/2016/01/19/sha-1-certificates-blocked-by-authenticode/

This will cause Atom problems with antivirus vendors. I tried to fix this myself, but signtool is abstracted as a script hidden on the Janky box. You need to add `/fd sha256` to the `signtool.exe` invocation

data.title: How to run Atom as root? - Linux
data.body:
I'm aware that we should avoid `sudo atom` since it'll write to the users `./atom` in their home directory as root which'll cause problems when not running atom as root. Normally you'd use `gksu/kdesu` or the newer [polkit](http://www.freedesktop.org/software/polkit/docs/latest/pkexec.1.html)/policykit with `pkexec`. The former does nothing, I setup a policy file for polkit and everything seemed good, Atom opened like a fresh install with no packages or past working tabs open. However I was unable to save a file getting a `permission denied` error. This worked fine with Gedit using polkit I could run `pkexec gedit` and save a file in the same location as root, with `pkexec atom` no file was saved as myself or root, just running `atom` would allow me to write a file as myself.

I believe this might have something to do with how Atom launches via a shell script instead of a binary directly? Would anyone know a way to fix this so I can use Atom for editing root owned files too?

I've got a thread on reddit seeking help as well: https://www.reddit.com/r/Atom/comments/42doe4/linux_running_atom_as_root/

I have the same problem if:
- I run the .exe with admin role (doing right click in the installer and `Run as administrator`)
- I move the installer in other folder (a customized folder) and again it is executed how admin.

Thanks

data.title: Restart button
data.body:
It would be nice to have a restart button (which is probably also offered when the editor crash (not-repsonding) message appears), which allows to restart Atom and restores the previous state immediately. 
Especially when you work with multiple windows and one crashes this is useful as you can be sure the correct session is restored.

data.title: When I save files, Atom makes duplicate copies of those files and folders arbitrarily on my hard drive.
data.body: ### Why is this happening and how do I prevent it? This also occurs when I rename a folder. When I'm in a file in the newly renamed folder and save, the old folder re-creates itself in the same directory.

data.title: Atom changed my markdown file to fit GFM automatically, which is NOT I want to save,what should I do?
data.body:
I want write markdown files with Atom, but the standard of markdown I want to use is not GFM. Therefore, if Atom changed my text to what I don't want,-- which is a huge waste of time,actually-- I can't use these markdown files normally. And I wonder whether there is some way to turn on/off this AUTO function.I really do not need it! I can only tolerate that it tell me what it wanna to change!
Following is the text I want:

```
 |  | A   | B   | C   | D|
|---| ----|---|---|---|
|A | 0.0 | 0.2 | 0.8 | 0.7|
|B | 0.2 | 0.0 | 0.9 | 0.8|
|C | 0.8 | 0.9 | 0.0 | 0.1|

```

and following is the version changed by Atom:

```
  | A   | B   | C   | D
- | --- | --- | --- | ---
A | 0.0 | 0.2 | 0.8 | 0.7
B | 0.2 | 0.0 | 0.9 | 0.8
C | 0.8 | 0.9 | 0.0 | 0.1
```

data.title: Temp files are created on Samba shares that aren't deleted on close, can't be deleted manually, and are only deleted upon unmounting the share
data.body:
Atom 1.4.0 on OS X 10.10.5.  The Samba share is on Windows 7 SP1.

I didn't see this behavior in 1.3.x.

Repro:
1.  Edit a plain text file on a Samba share.
2.  (Atom creates a `.tmp` file in the same directory.  Sometimes.  Not always.  I don't know the repro steps to force it to do so.  "Back Up Before Saving" is off, so this must be some kind of special temp file.)
3.  Close the tab for the plain text file.  Temp file isn't deleted.
4.  Close Atom.

Expected:

Atom deletes the temp file.

Actual:

Atom doesn't delete the temp file.  The file can't be deleted either via Finder in OS X or via Windows Explorer on the Windows box where the Samba share resides.

Finder gives the error "The operation can’t be completed because an unexpected error occurred (error code -8072)."

Windows Explorer says that the deletion can't complete without administrative rights and shows the elevation dialog.  Elevating doesn't help: another dialog is displayed saying that the file can't be deleted.  (I didn't capture the exact error text of the dialog.)  Attempting to take ownership of the file via `takeown` and modifying its ACLs via `icacls` fail:

```
> takeown /s MYBOXNAME /u MYBOXNAME\MyUsername /f . /r

WARNING: User credentials cannot be used for local connections.
ERROR: The current logged on user does not have ownership privileges on
       the file (or folder) "E:\work\current".

> icacls . /grant MYBOXNAME\MyUsername:f /t
processed file: .
processed file: .\notes.txt
.\notes.txt~RF449e304.TMP: Access is denied.
Successfully processed 2 files; Failed processing 1 files

>
```

`handles.exe` v3.46 (a Sysinternals tool by Mark Russinovich) shows that System has open handles on the temp file.

The temp file only gets deleted when the Samba share is unmounted from OS X.

Multiple temp files may be created, so reference above to "the temp file" are also applicable to "the temp files".  Again, I'm not sure under what circumstances Atom creates them, but the end result is that heavy Atom work on a Samba share leaves un-deletable temp files scattered about which screw up directory diffs, syncing directories, moving things around, uploading directories to other places, deleting directories that are no longer needed, recursively adding directories to source control, etc. etc. etc., and force an unmount and remount to resolve.

data.title: editor:*-to-next-word-boundary commands can't cross CRLF line boundary on OS X
data.body:
Atom 1.4.0 on OS X 10.10.5.

`editor:move-to-next-word-boundary` and `editor:delete-to-next-word-boundary` will not move/delete across a CRLF line boundary on OS X.  I haven't tested on other platforms.

`editor:*-to-previous-word-boundary` work fine.

This is a fairly recent regression, as the commands worked properly in 1.3.x.

FWIW, #7662 - "ctrl-delete does not remove CRLF" - was closed after PR https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/9937 landed in early December 2015.  That change was released with 1.4.0-beta0.  I haven't done a `git bisect` - but that could potentially be a place to start looking.

data.title: The editor has crashed (using atom-beautify on large file)
data.body: Just following orders: Was trying to use [atom-beautify](https://atom.io/packages/atom-beautify) on [the mongodb example dataset](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mongodb/docs-assets/primer-dataset/dataset.json), an 11.9 MB JSON file.
